title: How to Use a Graphic Flight Computer to Find Ground Speed and True Heading

steps.headline: Align the wind direction under the "True Index" mark by rotating the azimuth plate.
steps.description: If the winds are from 330° at 20 knots, align 330 under the true index.

steps.headline: Align the grid so the center grommet is over one of the heavy lines.
steps.description: It doesn't matter which line is used at this point.

steps.headline: Mark the wind speed by counting up from the center grommet.
steps.description: Each light line represents two knots. Mark a dot or an X in pencil on the 20 knot line (two heavy lines above the center grommet). This is the wind dot.

steps.headline: Rotate the azimuth plate until your desired course (true course) is aligned under the True Index mark.
Slide the grid until the wind dot is over your true airspeed.
steps.description: In this example, the true airspeed is 120 knots.

steps.headline: Read ground speed under the grommet.
steps.description: Ground speed is the speed of the aircraft over the ground and in this example is 138 knots.

steps.headline: Find the wind correction angle (WCA) by checking the number of degrees to the right or left between the center grommet and the wind dot.
steps.description: If the wind dot is to the right, the WCA is positive. If it is to the left, the WCA is negative. In the example, the wind correction angle is +4°.

steps.headline: Add or subtract the wind correction angle from the true course to find true heading.
steps.description: Adding 4° to 175 equals 179° for the true heading.

steps.headline: Add (or subtract) magnetic variation and compass deviation to find the compass heading to be flown.
steps.description: The variation is the difference between true north and magnetic north and can be found on a VFR or IFR chart. Easterly variations are subtracted and westerly variations are added. Compass deviation is printed on a placard under the magnetic compass in the airplane.
